text.author: Tom Kington
text.description: Italy's prime minister has cancelled official engagements due to the illness, local media report
text.title: Scarlet fever may force Silvio Berlusconi to miss EU summit

main.p: Italy's prime minister, Silvio Berlusconi, has contracted a mild form of scarlet fever, Italian media reported , leading him to cancel a public engagement and throwing into doubt his presence at a European Union summit this week.

The Italian daily Corriere della Sera said the 73-year-old prime minister may have contracted the illness from one of his five grandchildren. Symptoms including fever, rashes and a sore throat are treatable with antibiotics.
About 25,000 Italians catch scarlet fever each year.

Berlusconi's office did not comment on the report, but the financial daily Il Sole 24 Ore said political sources had confirmed the story and quoted the prime minister as saying: "How can I go on like this?"
Corriere reported that Berlusconi had pulled out of an event in earthquake struck Abruzzo today and might miss the EU summit in Brussels later this week.

Despite battling against prostate cancer in the 1990s and having a pacemaker fitted in 2006 after he collapsed on stage, Berlusconi has prided himself on his busy schedule since his reelection to a third term in 2008, despite suffering from acute neck pain.

During his three-day visit to Russia last week to celebrate Vladimir Putin's birthday, local media reported that Berlusconi briefly took the controls of a Russian aircraft and described "an enormous sense of power".

He returned to his villa near Milan at the weekend to hold talks with ministers in a bid to smooth out a row with his finance minister, Giulio Tremonti, over tax policy. On 16 November he will go back on trial accused of tax fraud, after Italy's constitutional court threw out a law granting him immunity.
Berlusconi's natural defences against illness are meanwhile undimmed, according to his personal physician Umberto Scapagnini, who has called his immune system "extraordinary".
